course.subject: FINA
course.name: Derivative Securities
course.description: This course covers options, forward contracts, futures contracts and swaps. By the end of this course, students will have a good knowledge of how derivative contracts work, how they are used and how they are priced.
course.prerequisites: FINA 2203 OR FINA 2303

reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is pretty decent. We had:
1) 3 Group Homework assignments (all adding up to 15% of the total grade. They all were returned too late to know where you went wrong. HW2 returned after the midterm, HW3 returned the day before the final)

2) Class Participation: 10% (Barely 10 people on average in the class)

3) Midterm: 30%

4) Final: 45%

I got nearly full for all the homeworks, and significantly above mean (dont know the SD) for the midterm. Mean was something like 81/100 for the class. Final scores not out yet
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is mainly concentrated on the midterm and final. Besdies the 2, the homework is a group assignment, so it should not take you long to finish them if you divide it up equitably.

Again, dont take it with him. You can score decently well if you practice, but some of the concepts are quite abstract, and hard to find explanations even on the internet. I have heard YAN, Ji is a pretty good prof. You would be better off taking it with him.

reviews.title: Great intuition and excellent teaching
reviews.comment_content:
1. Forward/Future Contracts on Financial Assets and Indices

4. different kinds of swaps
5. different kinds of options

9. theory vs reality
reviews.comment_teaching:
Definitely the best teaching in fina department. He has an amazing background (Tsinghua engineering and MIT economics PhD). Yet he never bombs your mind with terminology or mathematics. He places a great emphasis on intuition of derivative securities and explains it perfectly in plain language. It's both enjoyable and inspiring to attend his lecture.

The most difficult part is perhaps the BMS model. It's quite mathematics and beyond undergraduate level. But  professor will walk you through the intuition and only test how to use the formula as is shown in the corresponding lecture notes.   

There are exam version and non-exam version of lecture notes provided by professor JI Yan. it really saves a lot of time when you prepare for midterm or final.
reviews.comment_grading:
6 assginments 5% each
midterm 20%
final 40%
Attendance 10% (sign up on an attendance sheet, no iprs)

midterm and final are easy. he tested a lot how well you understand the intuitions. very simple mathematics involved. you may not feel good when you hand in your exam papers but the scores are normally satisfactory.

You need to spend more time on homework. 5% each is a lot. and some minor mistakes in each assign can take a toll on your final grade if you didn't take care of it.
reviews.comment_workload:
If you want to get the most of Ji Yan's teaching and get an A, you need to spend around 4 hours on the course. the time is mostly spent on homework. you better make sure every number and every explanation makes sense. besides, it's really a great opportunity to deepen your understanding of the course materials through homework.

Cheatsheet is not that important as usual. the process is perhaps more important than the cheatsheet itself. make sure you write down all critical equations because some of them are really lengthy. mark down some key intuitions so that you can finish your exam quickly. otherwise it would be torturing to recall all you learn in class with the clock ticking.

reviews.author: ksk105
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers one of the most exciting yet fundamental areas in finance: derivative securities. The global derivatives market is one of the most fast-growing markets, with over $600 trillion notional value in total. In the modern financial architecture, financial derivatives can be the most challenging and exotic securities traded by institutional specialists, while at the same time, they can also be the basic securities commonly traded by retail investors such as S&P 500 Index Options. Beyond trading, the basic ideas of financial derivatives serve as building blocks to understand a much broader class of financial problems, such as complex asset portfolios, strategic corporate decisions, and stages in venture capital investing. Therefore, It is as important as ever to understand both the strategic opportunities offered by these derivative instruments and the risks they imply.

We discuss a wide range of applications, including the use of derivatives in asset management, the valuation of corporate securities such as stocks and corporate bonds with embedded options, interest rate derivatives, credit derivatives, as well as crude oil derivatives. In addition to theoretical discussions,
we also emphasize practical considerations of implementing strategies using derivatives as tools, especially when no-arbitrage conditions do not hold.

Topic 1: Introduction to Derivatives
L1 - Introduction to Derivatives

Topic 2: Forwards and Futures
L2 - Forward and Futures contracts
L3 - Forwards and Futures on commodities
L4 - Forwards and Futures on currencies
L5 - Forwards and Futures on interest rates

Topic 3: Swaps
L6 - Swaps

Topic 4: Options Basics
L7 - Introduction to options
L8 - Option Trading Strategies

Topic 5: Binomial Trees
L9 - Binomial Tree Models
L10 - Multi-step Binomial Tree Models

Topic 6: Black-Scholes-Merton model
L11 - The Black-Scholes-Merton Model
L12 - Delta Hedging in the BSM Model
L13 - Some issues with the BSM Model

Topic 7: Exotic options and Default
L14 - American and Exotic Options
L15 - Default modeling and credit derivatives
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof has an accent which made it difficult sometimes. But he was always happy to answer our questions and make sure we understand what was happening all the time. Prof also used a lot of examples to simplify the topics and make them easier for us to understand. He focuses more on intuition more than mathematical explanations. So, rather than memorizing examples in ppt or homework, it is more useful to really understand the intuition behind as exam questions won't be exactly the same as those in the ppt or homework.

reviews.comment_content:
This course will cover different types of derivatives like forward, future, swap and also option.

Topic 1: Introduction
Topic 2 - 7: Forward (with various kinds like foreign exchange)
Topic 8 - 10: Swap

reviews.comment_teaching: Despite having some kind of Mainland accent, I actually like the way how he teaches. He won't behave like a machine, reading out all the content of the slides. Instead, he really mixes the teaching with some real life examples, and also gives some examples by writing on the blackboard (Erm tho his handwriting is very UGLY and UNCLEAR). He explains the things in a relatively funnier way so that I did not skip most of the lessons. Even though he said he might suddenly check our attendance and might deduct our score, he did not do so eventually, because our attendance rate are generally quite high.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final Grade: A+

The grading is quite good I think. I guess it is absolute grading as I think it is impossible for me to get an A+ for grading by curve.

Assignment (20%): 100/100
Midterm (30%): 100/100 -- Mean: 82/100
Final (50%): 92/100 -- Mean: 78/100

The midterm is very simple and the upper quartile is 93.
The final is very tricky, but the upper quartile is 93.

So the grading is really quite lenient if I can obtain an A+ with such marks.
reviews.comment_workload: Moderate to high. There are in total 5 assignments, and the questions are difficult (but once you understand how the answers are derived you will start understanding the concepts). Professor Zhu didn't teach very fast, so that it is still okay to digest the content within the class. But it is also crucial to read through the notes again and again after class. So the workload is acceptable.

Prof. JI is knowledgeble in this area. He is very willing to answer students questions. For easy questions, you can straightly ask him in-class; and for longer or more complicated ones, you can send him emails and he will reply very soon. reviews.author: 數學研究生
reviews.title: Very Good Course, very useful
reviews.comment_content:
This course mainly describes and introduces different types of fixed income and derivatives, mainly derivatives.
For the first part of the life, it includes forward contracts: for stocks, for interest rates(FRA), for currency...., futures and swaps.
The remaining parts are the options, European and American, exotic options, credit spread, and default probability etc.

Those concepts and derivatives are very important if you want to work as sell side in future.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I like this Professor very much, he is humorous and uses a lot of real life examples to explain the content, like how 摩根赤柱 earns money by using some of the derivatives.

He is always helpful in answering students' questions. Even I can discuss real life problems to him, his knowledge is very very board. Qsinghua University First Honor and MIT PHD, but very generous to the students. He always smiles and teaches very well, not just for the content but also some real life problems.

I only know he teaches this course each semester, don't know if he will teach other courses as well, he is really great, one of the best professor in HKUST.
reviews.comment_grading:
6 homework, easy homework, normally you have two weeks to finish one. 4-5 questions for each problem set.

Midterm: 4 questions, 2 hours, very easy midterm, you can bring a piece of A4 paper as your cheat sheet, but not useful because those calculations are very straight forward and easy. Just plug in the numbers, but normally you can remember the formulas.

Final Exam: 5 questions, 2 hours, a little bit difficult than the midterm exam, somehow you need your 'wisdom' to show that you are suitable in this field. Like constructing arbitrage opportunity, pricing an exotic option(will not be taught, use No Arbitrage Principle), hedge your portfolio etc.

Mean is high, 90+/100, but it should be fine as Professor Yan is very kind.

New Update: Exam mean: 72.8, SD:18
reviews.comment_workload:
As mentioned, 6 hw, 2 weeks for one, easy and can work as a group but not copy directly from each other.

Final Exam will just cover the later part(after swaps), as well as you can use a piece of cheat sheet(double sides), you should not worry for this.

reviews.comment_teaching:
A good (and young?) professor for this course since he himself is a trader. Andrew has an Engineering degree but switched to the Finance field in his further studies.

He can speak English very fluently and can communicate well with both local and non-local students. He always tried his best to explain the concepts to students using examples (with the aid of his tablet and excel).

The pace of teaching was also fine. Andrew did not only spend time quickly going through the slides. In many of his lectures, he told us real-life trading things (not tested) so if you are interested in trading you will be very happy to listen. He also told jokes frequently to make the lectures less intense.

You can ask Andrew questions anonymously on the website he provided and he will reply them in Canvas announcements. He was also very nice that he gave us hints before the two exams

Lecture videos were uploaded to Canvas, but the people who recorded them sometimes did not catch up the screens timely.

In my opinion, for those who have no idea what derivatives are before taking this course (like me), what calls and puts are, it will be a bit hard for you to catch up.
